Lesson 3: Collaborative and Shared Decision Making

Image by rawpixel.com under Freepik

In order to have a program of quality, collaboration and shared decision-making must be integral components of the program. As we learned from NAEYC Program Standards and Great Start to Quality, collaborative and shared decision making builds trust and enthusiasm for making program changes. Throughout the year, not only during the evaluation process, the program must offer families and staff opportunities to help make decisions to improve the program.

Some best practices for collaborative and shared decision making include:

  • Involving administrators, families, and staff in a comprehensive program evaluation that measures progress toward the program’s goals and objectives, at least annually.
  • Facilitating meetings of all staff and families to consult on program planning and ongoing program operations at least annually.
  • Inviting families to participate in program-level decisions and wider advocacy efforts.
  • Encouraging and inviting families to advocate for early childhood education in the wider community.
  • Surveying family and staff about their experiences in the program.
  • Reporting annual evaluation findings with families, staff, and appropriate advisory and governance boards.
  • Using the annual evaluation as an occasion for recognizing strengths, celebrating improvements, and identifying areas for growth.
  • Establishing goals with input from staff and families.
